Can Diabetic Foot Charcot Be Reversed

Charcot Foot is a common complication of diabetes, causing bone and joint damage through Neuropathy. It is actually a type of paralysis caused by nerve damage, mostly around the foot due to underlying disease like Diabetes. Many people living with diabetes suffer from complications like Charcot Foot which may appear suddenly and can cause deformity in multiple joints, even if their blood glucose levels are well managed.

Unfortunately, the Charcot phenomenon itself cannot be reversed. The good news, however, is that with early detection and prompt treatment, the deformities and destruction caused by the condition can be reversed.

Treatment for Charcot foot is aimed at stopping further destruction of the joint and restoring it to a more normal alignment. Slowing down the progression of this disease is the key in keeping Charcot Foot from getting worse. Prompt evaluation and treatment of Charcot Foot is the best way to Ensure that the foot does not suffer any further damage.

The treatment for Charcot foot may involve a variety of therapies, such as:

– Weight bearingactivity restriction and/or use of compression garments

– Wearing orthopedic shoeswhich gently “cage” the foot and ankle tohelp in realigning the joints

– Surgery in severe cases to fixbone and joint deformity, or to realignthe bones

– Anti-inflammatory medications to reduce swelling and pain

– Physical therapythat may help maintain or improverange of motion in the affected joint

– Injections to relieve pain and reduce inflammation

It is important to note that Timely and proper care are essential to prevent further damage and to restore the foot to as normal as possible and return the patient to a more active lifestyle.

If correctly diagnosed and promptly treated, Charcot foot can be most successfully managed. It is true that people with diabetes sometimes develop Charcot Foot, and the condition needs to be treated quickly and properly. This is why it is so important to keep a close check on your feet and report any new foot pain or deformity to your doctor at once.
